The s package

This chapter provides a very brief overview of the s package and its most important classes.

The s package can be compared to whatâ€™s called standard library in other programing languages. It provides some of the most important classes and value types to write meaningful programs.

Hint

This chapter only introduces the most important classes although there are many more.

You can browse the whole API of the s package here.

ğŸ‘Œ ğŸš‚ ğŸš€ ğŸ”£

Youâ€™ve already got to know the types ğŸ‘Œ ğŸš‚ ğŸš€ ğŸ”£ in a previous chapter. These types are, of course, also defined in the s package.

ğŸ”¡ Strings

In Emojicode a string is an ordered immutable collection of symbols (or easily speaking a text). Strings are represented by the ğŸ”¡ class which represent a collection of ğŸ”£, a primitive type representing a single Unicode code point.

String Literals

You can include strings in your code by surrounding the characters by a pair of ğŸ”¤:

ğŸ¦ aString ğŸ”¤This is a string.ğŸ”¤

You can of course also create an empty string:

ğŸ¦ emptyString ğŸ”¤ğŸ”¤

Such a string is 0 symbols long and doesnâ€™t have any value.

Obviously, you cannot just include the ğŸ”¤ symbol in a string literal as it would be understood as the ending of the string. You can however escape the ğŸ”¤ using the âŒ.

ğŸ¦ aboutStringLiterals ğŸ”¤A string literal begins with a âŒğŸ”¤ symbol.ğŸ”¤

If you want to include the âŒ symbol in a string literal you will need to escape it as well:

ğŸ¦ theEscapeSymbol ğŸ”¤The escape character is âŒâŒ (red cross).ğŸ”¤

The escape character can also be used to produce the following characters:

  • âŒâŒ âŒ
  • âŒn New line (U+A0)
  • âŒt Tab (U+09)
  • âŒr Carriage return (U+0D)
  • âŒe Escape (U+1B)

All other combinations of a âŒ and another character lead to a compiler error.

Formally, the syntax is:

string-literal âŸ¶ ğŸ”¤ [string-literal-characters] ğŸ”¤
string-literal-characters âŸ¶ string-literal-character |  string-literal-character string-literal-characters
string-literal-character âŸ¶ unicode except ğŸ”¤ except âŒ | string-escape-sequence
string-escape-sequence âŸ¶ âŒ string-escape-tail
string-escape-tail âŸ¶ n | t | r | e

Comparing Strings

If you want to determine whether to strings represent the same value, you can use the equality method ğŸ˜›.

ğŸ˜› ğŸªğŸ”¤StrawğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤berriesğŸ”¤ğŸª ğŸ”¤StrawberriesğŸ”¤
Hint

Note that the example above used a method call. ğŸ˜› is a method defined in the ğŸ”¡ class. Youâ€™ll learn more about classes and methods in the next chapter. For now, just remember that methods are called by placing an emoji before the object on which the method should be called.

Concatenating Strings

To add two or more strings together (concatenate) you should use the ğŸª language struct. Wrap all strings you want to concatenate between two ğŸª. They will get concatenated in order of appearance into one string.

ğŸ¦ string1 ğŸ”¤Hello ğŸ”¤
ğŸ¦ string2 ğŸ”¤my dearğŸ”¤

ğŸ˜€ ğŸª string1 string2 ğŸ”¤ World!ğŸ”¤ ğŸª

ğŸªs are the most efficient way of concatenating strings as the compiler can ğŸªoptimize the concatenation. Please note that ğŸªs are not methods but part of the language.

The syntax formally is:

concatenate-literal âŸ¶ ğŸª concatenate-expressions ğŸª
concatenate-expressions âŸ¶ concatenate-expression | concatenate-expression concatenate-expressions
concatenate-expression âŸ¶ expression except concatenate-literal

String Pooling

At compile time all strings will be pooled. This means that each string literal with the same value occurs only once in the bytecode file and at runtime equal strings created from string literals will be represented by the same object.

Consider the following example. While the first comparison of object references will evaluate to true, the second one wonâ€™t.

ğŸ˜œ ğŸ”¤StrawberriesğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤StrawberriesğŸ”¤ ğŸ‘´true
ğŸ˜œ ğŸªğŸ”¤StrawğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤berriesğŸ”¤ğŸª ğŸ”¤StrawberriesğŸ”¤ ğŸ‘´false
Caution

Never use ğŸ˜œ to compare strings. Use ğŸ˜› instead.

String Mutablility

Strings are immutable. This means that you canâ€™t modify any string. You can however call methods on strings that return modified copies of the orginal string, but those themselves are then immutable again.

ğŸ¨ Lists

Lists are ordered mutable collections of values. They are represeneted by the ğŸ¨ class. Their sizes are theoretically unlimited, but practically hardware and the fact that Emojicodeâ€™s integers have an upper bound makes them limited.

Lists are optimized for fast by index access. You can access by index, pop and append in O(1).

List indexing starts at 0, as in C or Java. A negative index is assumed to be relative to the end of the list â€” that is, an index of -1 indicates the last element of the array, -2 is the next to last element in the array, and so on.

The ğŸ¨ Type

The ğŸ¨ class is generic and needs to know of what type the values are. If you use the class name you will also have to specify this generic argument. To specify a list that can hold strings you would write:

ğŸ¨ğŸšğŸ”¡

If you created a list like this

ğŸ® list ğŸ”· ğŸ¨ğŸšğŸ”¡ ğŸ¸

you would only be able to add strings to the list and you will always get back strings from the list. (The syntax used above will be discussed in Classes.)

List Literals

You can create a list just by listing the values for the list between ğŸ¨ and ğŸ†. The example below creates a list with the values 14, 67, 2434.

ğŸ¨ 14 67 2434 ğŸ†

The compiler will try to infer the generic type argument for the list.

list-literal âŸ¶ ğŸ¨ [expressions] ğŸ†
expressions âŸ¶ expression | expression expressions

ğŸ¯ Dictionaries

Dictionaries can be used to assign values to string keys. The size of a dictionary is theoretically unlimited.

The ğŸ¯ Type

The ğŸ¯ class is also generic and requires you to specify the type of the values. For instance if the values were booleans the type would be written like this:

ğŸ¯ğŸšğŸ‘Œ

Dictionary Literals

The shortcut syntax to create a dictionary is:

dictionary-literal âŸ¶ ğŸ¯ [kv-pairs] ğŸ†
kv-pairs âŸ¶ kv-pair kv-pairs | kv-pair
kv-pair âŸ¶ key expression
key âŸ¶ expression

key must be a string. The compiler will try to infer the generic type argument for the dictionary.

Hereâ€™s an example for a dictionary that associates artists with their birthplaces:

ğŸ¯
  ğŸ”¤Aaron CoplandğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤BrooklynğŸ”¤
  ğŸ”¤Michael JacksonğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤GaryğŸ”¤
  ğŸ”¤FalcoğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤ViennağŸ”¤
ğŸ†

â© Ranges

Emojicode supports a range type called â©. A range is an immutable sequence of numbers, or more strictly speaking of integers.

A range is always defined by three values: start, stop and step.

Every number f(x) = start + x * step that matches the constraint start â‰¤ f(x) < stop is an element of the range. If step is negative the constraint stop < f(x) â‰¤ start applies instead.

Ranges can be created by using the shortcut syntax, which is depending on your needs either

range-literal âŸ¶ range-literal-with-step range-literal-without-step
range-literal-with-step âŸ¶ â­ start stop step
start âŸ¶ expression
stop âŸ¶ expression
step âŸ¶ expression

or

range-literal-without-step âŸ¶ â© start stop

The latter uses 1 as step value if start is less than stop, otherwise -1 is used as step value. If you provide 0 as step value step will be set to an appropriate value as described before.

Ranges can be very helpful in combination with ğŸ”‚ if you need to repeat something for a specific number of times:

ğŸ”‚ i â­ 0 10 2 ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¡ i 10
ğŸ‰

ğŸ”‚ i â© 0 10 ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¡ i 10
ğŸ‰

ğŸ”‚ i â© 10 0 ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¡ i 10
ğŸ‰

ğŸ”‚ i â­ 100 -10 -10 ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¡ i 10
ğŸ‰
